data.title: Bridge Pedal, Oregon City PorchFest and OMSI Star Party: 11 things to do this week
data.meta_description: Check out this list of events for the week of Aug. 9-15, 2024.
data.text:
We’ve got festivals galore happening this weekend with events that celebrate everything from cover bands to garlic to environmental education, as well as local art and Scandinavian culture. This Sunday also brings the return of the Providence Bridge Pedal. Grab your bike and take in some of the city’s best views.

Junction City Scandinavian Festival

Each year Junction City offers a four-day event with each day honoring one country in this order: Finland, Norway, Sweden and Denmark. The days rotate each year. Expect music, traditional dances, costumes, and of course the delicious foods of those countries.

10 a.m.-9 p.m. Thursday-Saturday, 10 a.m.-8 p.m. Sunday, Aug. 8-11, in venues around Junction City; free admission; junctioncityscandia.org.

Vancouver Craft Beer & Wine Fest

Are you up for cover bands and $5 pints all day? Sunday is your day at the Vancouver Craft Beer & Wine Fest. The event is Friday-Sunday and offers plenty of live music from cover bands honoring Creedence, Queen, Cheap Trick and the Cars. Bring a lawn chair or blanket, and soak in the sun as well as regional beers, ciders and wines.

5-10 p.m. Friday, noon-10 p.m. Saturday, noon-5 p.m. Sunday, Aug. 9-11, Esther Short Park, 605 Esther St., Vancouver; admission prices vary by day. This is a 21 and older only event. More info at thecraftwinefest.com.

Ghosts of Summer Halloween Festival and Market We’re barely halfway through summer, but spooky things come out early during this pre-Halloween Festival and Market. Enjoy 2 evenings of ghostly delights and offerings from more than 80 vendors. Costumes are encouraged. There’s also a “Make & Sip” event where participants can create their own plant monster (extra fee).

7-11:30 p.m. Friday-Saturday Aug. 9-10, The Redd, 831 S.E. Salmon St.; general admission $12; ghostsofsummerpdx.com/get-tickets.

Oregon City PorchFest

Oregon City comes alive this weekend and it’s bringing the show to neighborhoods. More than 50 groups will offer live music (including Redhead Darling), theater performances, comedy, dance and more. Walk or bike to as many as 15 porches or stages in your neighborhood for a shot of free entertainment without having to brave traffic and parking. The website offers a map of performance destinations. Check it out.

Entertainment starts 5 p.m. Friday-Saturday, Aug. 9-10, at 15 locations in Oregon City; free; oregoncityporchfest.com.

Tillamook County Fair

This “Blue-Ribbon” fair offers Open Class and 4-H/FFA exhibits that Tillamook County residents have prepared for all year, as well as free entertainment and live music concerts, exotic animal displays, horse racing, pig and Ford races, and carnival games and rides.

10 a.m.-10 p.m. Thursday-Saturday, Aug. 8-10, Tillamook County Fairgrounds, 4603 Third St., Tillamook; tillamookfair.com/p/fair-info.

North Plains Elephant Garlic Festival

Someone should make sure the garlic-loving toddler in the above video gets a chance to celebrate garlic in all its odiferous glory during the annual party in North Plains. Expect plenty of food booths with garlic as a central ingredient, a parade, live music, craft vendors, beer and wine garden, a car show and a book sale.

Noon-11 p.m. Friday, 10 a.m.-11 p.m. Saturday, 10 a.m.-4 p.m. Sunday, Aug. 9-11, Jessie Mays Community Park, 30975 N.W. Hillcrest St., North Plains; free admission; funstinks.com.

Washougal Art Festival

Each year a few dozen visual artists gather with musicians and meet other artists and community members interested in their work. The festival facilitates a free flow of information, ideas and feedback for the artists and also provides a way for local residents and visitors to become engaged with art in a more hands-on way.

9 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturday, Aug. 10, Reflection Plaza, 1703 Main St., downtown Washougal; free admission; washougalarts.org.

Englewood Forest Festival (Salem)

Head to Salem and find a full day of music and dance performances on two stages, as well as 50 local art vendors and presentations from organizations focused on environmental education. Performers include Ty Curtis, Paradise of Samoa, Aztec Dancers, Gail Gage Jazz, and Salem Aerial Dance Co. Learn what you can do in your own yards, gardens, and local streams to protect trees, birds and water. The free family-friendly event takes place in the historic tree-filled Englewood Park,

10 a.m.-4 p.m. Saturday, Aug. 10, Englewood Park, 1260 19th St. N.E. Salem; free; englewoodforestfestival.org

Providence Bridge Pedal

Portland is filled with bridges, but two of the largest are closed to anything other than motorized vehicles for 264 days a year. The annual Bridge Pedal is the one day each year bicyclists and even pedestrians get to take in the views from the top decks of both the Marquam and Fremont bridges. There are several ride lengths to choose from, and one “Bridge Stride” for walkers that crosses the Fremont Bridge. Bike riders can kick off the festivities at sunrise with a light breakfast on the top of the Fremont Bridge. Check the website for more details.

Ride start times vary Sunday, Aug. 11, with most rides (but not all) kicking off from Southwest Naito Parkway, registration fees vary; providence.org/lp/bridge-pedal.

OMSI Star Party: Perseid Meteor Shower

If the weather cooperates Monday night will be OMSI’s largest star party of the year as people from around the Pacific Northwest gather at Rooster Rock State Park in the Columbia River Gorge to watch and enjoy the wonder of the Perseid Meteor Shower. The event, sponsored by OMSI, Rose City Astronomers, and Oregon Parks and Recreation, will offer telescopes set up for attendees to use. OMSI staff will be give informal talks about the meteor shower, constellations, and the summer night sky.

At dusk, Monday, Aug. 12, Rooster Rock State Park, 22 miles east of Portland on Interstate 84, exit 25; free admission, parking is $5 per vehicle; omsi.edu/events/omsi-star-party.

“Romeo and Juliet” Anonymous Theatre Company

Anonymous Theatre does things a little differently. Find out what it’s like when audiences AND actors experience a play together for the first time.

It works like this: Auditions are held in secret. The play is cast in secret. Cast members rehearse the show individually and secretly. Actors are not told the identity of the other cast members. On the night of the performance, the actors arrive at the theater as though they are members of the audience. They take their seats, read their programs, chat with their neighbors, and when the house lights dim, and the play begins, each actor delivers their first line from their seat.

If that sounds like your cup of tea, check out the performance Monday night.

7 p.m. Monday, Aug. 12, U.S. Bank Main Stage, The Armory, 128 N.W. 11th Ave.; tickets are pay-what-you-will beginning at $40; pcs.org/events/anonymous-romeo-and-juliet.

- If you have events you’d like to see highlighted at OregonLive.com or in the weekly printed A&E section of The Oregonian, please email submissions to events@oregonian.com at least three weeks prior to the start of your event. Digital images or links to videos are helpful.

— Rosemarie Stein

503-221-4376, events@oregonian.com ; @trafficportland
